001package squidpony.squidai;
002
003import squidpony.squidgrid.Radius;
004
005import java.awt.Point;
006import java.util.LinkedHashMap;
007
008/**
009 * Static utilities for use in AOE and anything else that might need HashMaps of Point keys to Double values.
010 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 7/13/2015.
011 */
012public class AreaUtils {
013    /**
014     * This takes a 2D boolean array and returns a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, but will only use the value
015     * 1.0, and only for positions in map that have as their boolean element true.
016     * @param map width by height, commonly generated by FOV methods
017     * @return a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, but the only value used is 1.0
018     */
019    public static LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> arrayToHashMap(boolean[][] map)
020    {
021        LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> ret = new LinkedHashMap<>();
022        for(int i = 0; i < map.length; i++)
023        {
024            for(int j = 0; j < map[i].length; j++)
025            {
026                if(map[i][j])
027                    ret.put(new Point(i, j), 1.0);
028            }
029        }
030        return ret;
031    }
032
033    /**
034     * This takes a 2D double array called map and returns a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, and will have a key
035     * for every position in map that is greater than 0.0, with values equal to those in map.
036     * @param map width by height, commonly generated by FOV methods
037     * @return a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, with values all greater than 0.0
038     */
039    public static LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> arrayToHashMap(double[][] map)
040    {
041        LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> ret = new LinkedHashMap<>();
042        for(int i = 0; i < map.length; i++)
043        {
044            for(int j = 0; j < map[i].length; j++)
045            {
046                if(map[i][j] > 0.0)
047                    ret.put(new Point(i, j), map[i][j]);
048            }
049        }
050        return ret;
051    }
052
053    /**
054     * This takes a 2D double array and returns a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, but will only use the value
055     * 1.0, and only does this if the passed double[][] has a value at that position that is greater than cutoff.
056     * For example, a cutoff of 0.3 will make all elements in the 2D array that are 0.3 or less be ignored and not put
057     * into the HashMap, but all elements that are greater than 0.3 will be placed in as 1.0.
058     * @param map width by height, commonly generated by FOV methods
059     * @param cutoff any elements greater than this will be 1.0 in the return, anything else will be ignored
060     * @return a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, but the only value used is 1.0
061     */
062    public static LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> arrayToHashMap(double[][] map, double cutoff)
063    {
064        LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> ret = new LinkedHashMap<>();
065        for(int i = 0; i < map.length; i++)
066        {
067            for(int j = 0; j < map[i].length; j++)
068            {
069                if(map[i][j] > cutoff)
070                    ret.put(new Point(i, j), 1.0);
071            }
072        }
073        return ret;
074    }
075
076    /**
077     * This takes a DijkstraMap that has already completed a scan() and returns a HashMap of Point keys to Double
078     * values, and will have a key for every position that was reached in the DijkstraMap, with 1.0 as the only value.
079     * @param map a double[][] returned by a DijkstraMap running its scan()
080     * @return a HashMap of Point keys to Double values, with values of 1.0 only
081     */
082    public static LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> dijkstraToHashMap(double[][] map)
083    {
084        LinkedHashMap<Point, Double> ret = new LinkedHashMap<>();
085        for(int i = 0; i < map.length; i++)
086        {
087            for(int j = 0; j < map[i].length; j++)
088            {
089                if(map[i][j] < DijkstraMap.WALL)
090                    ret.put(new Point(i, j), 1.0);
091            }
092        }
093        return ret;
094    }
095
096    /**
097     * Checks that the given end Point can be targeted from the given origin Point given the directional targeting
098     * rules specified by limit. If any of the arguments are null, returns true (it assumes that any limits are not
099     * valid and don't restrict anything). The following Radius enum values for limit have the following meanings:
100     *
101     * <ul>
102     *     <li>Radius.CIRCLE, Radius.SPHERE, Radius.SQUARE or RADIUS.CUBE will only consider Points to be valid targets
103     *     if they are along a straight line with an angle that is a multiple of 45 degrees, relative to the positive x
104     *     axis. Essentially, this limits the points to those a queen could move to in chess.</li>
105     *     <li>Radius.DIAMOND or Radius.OCTAHEDRON will cause the AOE to only consider Points to be valid targets if
106     *     they are along a straight line with an angle that is a multiple of 90 degrees, relative to the positive x
107     *     axis. Essentially, this limits the points to those a rook could move to in chess.</li>
108     * </ul>
109     *
110     * @param limit DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON for rook-like, other enum values for queen-like, null for unrestricted
111     * @param origin where the user is
112     * @param end where the point we want to verify is
113     * @return true if the point is a valid target or if the limits are invalid (non-restricting), false otherwise
114     */
115    public static boolean verifyLimit(Radius limit, Point origin, Point end)
116    {
117        if (limit != null && origin != null && end != null) {
118            switch (limit) {
119                case SQUARE:
120                case CUBE:
121                case CIRCLE:
122                case SPHERE:
123                    if(Math.abs(end.x - origin.x) == Math.abs(end.y - origin.y))
124                    {
125                        return true;
126                    }
127                case DIAMOND:
128                case OCTAHEDRON:
129                    if(end.x == origin.x || end.y == origin.y)
130                    {
131                        return true;
132                    }
133                    break;
134            }
135            return false;
136        }
137        else
138            return true;
139    }
140}
